loans.name: Ramkumari

texts.en:
Ramkumari is 37 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Many years ago, she established her vegetable farming business. Working 7 days a week and 7 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 6 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy seeds and fertilizers. In the future, She plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica lives in Garcia Hernandez, Bohol, with her family. She is 34 years old and has two children, aged seven and nine. Jessica and her husband operate a transportation business with their mini-bus, or multicab, as it is called by locals. She also buys and sells rice and bread.

Jessica is asking for a loan to have a bigger supply of rice and bread that she can resell at a profit. Her income provides her family with food and money to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more rice and bread to sell

loans.name: Baker

texts.en:
Baker is 42-year-old man from Jabalia city, married and a father to three kids. Baker was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Baker took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house. The loan will allow Baker to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Baker appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en:
Ghassan is 22-year-old young man from Jabalia city. Ghassan was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Ghassan took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house.

The loan will allow Ghassan to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Ghassan appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Maria Cecilia

texts.es: María es una mujer de 47 años de edad cuenta con vivienda propia desde hace 22 años y en ella vive actualmente junto a su compañero de vida y sus 2 hijos de 18 y 19 años de edad, a los que ha logrado sacar adelante con mucho esfuerzo. María se gana la vida con la venta de ropa de forma ambulante, actividad que realiza recorriendo las principales calles de su municipio, por lo que se siente feliz. María desea cambiar el techo de su vivienda, ya que como se observa en la fotografía, las láminas de su vivienda se encuentran deterioradas, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: lámina galvanizada, madera, clavos ya alambre para cambiar el techo de su vivienda y protegerse de la lluvia.
texts.en: Maria is a 47 year old woman who has had her own home for 22 years, where she currently lives with her life partner and 2 children age 18 and 19. She has helped them get ahead with lots of hard work. Maria makes a living in traveling clothes sales, which she does on the main streets of her town. It makes her feel happy. Maria wants to change the roof on her house because, as seen in the photo, the tiles are deteriorated. She is requesting a FUSAI loan to invest in: galvanized sheet, wood, nails, and wire to change the roof on her home and protect it from the rain.

loans.use: to invest in: galvanized sheet, wood, nails, and wire to change the roof on her home and protect it from the rain.

loans.name: Jennybeb

texts.en:
Jennybeb, 33 years old, is from Badian, Cebu. She is married with two young children. Looking after them is a full-time job but she has been able to add two businesses that allow her to earn an income. She raises hogs and runs a sari-sari (general) store to help provide for her children.

Jennybeb is asking for a loan to have additional capital that she can use to buy more merchandise, such as cooking oil, vinegar, soy sauce, salt, canned goods, diapers, coffee and biscuits. She hopes that from the proceeds of her business she can successfully send her children to school for a bright future.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, vinegar, soy sauce, salt, canned goods, diapers, coffee and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a 55-year-old woman with one daughter, who is 18 years old. She is from Badian, Cebu. She is engaged in selling coconut wine and renting out a videoke machine for events.

Helen is doing well with her coconut wine, but sometimes she runs out of stock to make vinegar. She is asking a loan to buy more coconut wine from "mananggite" (coconut farmers who gather coconut wine).

Helen dreams of making her business sustainable and increasing her business profits someday.

loans.use: to buy more coconut wine

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Irine, 37 years old, is sitting next to her styro box, which serves as her storage for fresh fish. Next to her are small white balls called floaters that will be attached to fishing nets and used for fishing. Irine sells fish for a living since her husband is a fisherman. She is asking a loan to buy even more fish from other fishermen to increase her sales and profit.

Her income ensures her family will have food for their three children and will be able to maintain their fishing business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Jerilyn

texts.en:
Jerilyn is a married woman from Garcia Hernandez, Bohol. She runs a general store that sells canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, noodles, bath soap, detergent, seasoning and shampoo. She has been in this business for two years.

Jerilyn is asking a loan to buy liquor, soft drinks, chips, canned sardines, sugar, cooking oil, rice and salt. As her stock increases, her sales will definitely follow.

In the future, Jerilyn would like to build and expand her business to experience financial stability.

loans.use: to  buy liquor, soft drinks, chips, canned sardines, sugar, cooking oil, rice and salt.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is a dedicated member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT). She’s blessed that her previous loan of Php 22,000 was granted which has been an additional capital for the business. Sincerest gratitude she wants to send to CCT and all lenders.

Lilibeth aims to have her own one-stop-shop someday where she can offer products on demand and complete items. She wants to continually support her children’s educational expenses as well. However, most of her customers are her neighbors, that’s why she could not avoid to lend them products. To compensate, Lilibeth decided to apply for another loan of Php 30,000 to buy stocks of grocery items. She’s hopeful that CCT would once more grant her request for her business to have wide variety of choices.

Lilibeth has been consistent in attending CCT fellowship group that consist of 15 to 30 members where she hears the word of God and testimonies from partners, this made her to become strong spiritually and dependent to God on every occasion.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her variety store business.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia, an entrepreneur from Valencia, Bohol, has owned a small grocery store for three years now.

Her business consists of selling food, rice, sugar, oil, beans, soda and other snack foods. The business is the source of her daily income.

Amelia needs to make further investments in her store, however she lacks the funds to do so. As of this time, Amelia is requesting a loan to buy additional items or merchandise to sell like rice, sugar, canned goods, sodas and other snack foods.

With the loan, Amelia will be able to augment her stock to attract more customers, thus giving her the chance of increasing her sales.

Amelia hopes to make her business grow and become more sustainable.

loans.use: to buy  rice, sugar, canned goods, sodas and other snack foods

loans.name: Huynh

texts.en: Mrs. Huynh  is 64 years old, married and has three children. She  has been raising hogs for almost 25 years now. This is her main source of income. She is in need of capital to support her livelihood. She is asking for a loan to buy pig feed and additional pigs. With these, she could maximize the resources available and improve her income. She dreams of handling her income successfully, to continue to support the education of her children, so they have a brighter future.

loans.use: to buy pig feed and additional pigs.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is an enterprising 26-year-old farmer from the Kapyeso, Kapsowar area of Kenya. She is the hardworking, energetic mother of four children. For the past five years she has been a farmer, gaining a lot of practical experience in doing so. Through her farming income she has always assured her family of a decent meal and other basic needs.

Agnes is now applying for a 20,000 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy seeds and move into horticultural farming. Kapyeso area has good weather patterns and conditions that support farming activities. It has good roads and a good transportation network. With these favorable conditions she is sure that she will be able to increase her business and reap the maximum in profits.
Being a woman and accessing funds in Africa is very challenging, but Agnes feels relieved knowing there are institutions that help enterprising women like her. She is much disciplined with her finances and hopes that through her accumulated profits she will be able to improve her living conditions and also secure the future of her children.

loans.use: To buy seeds and start horticulture farming

loans.name: Abdullaziz

texts.en:
Abdullaziz is a Babban Gona farmer.  Abdullaziz is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty, renewing his dreams of gaining wealth someday. Traditionally, Abdullaziz would have had to sell his maize at Harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan Abdullaziz can store his maize at harvest and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. Benefiting from Babban Gona’s marketing support, Abdullaziz has the opportunity to generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. 

Abdullaziz is thankful that he no longer has to worry about having no money to feed his family and children and looks forward to using his additional earnings to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Rakai Ptc School

texts.en:
This is Patrick. He is the Administrator of Rakai PTC School, a mixed school in the Rural area of Rakai with 300 students. Rakai PTC School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children.

Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day.

Rakai PTC School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Patrick ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his student’s concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: to purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Rosa Isela

texts.es:
Rosa Isela es una mujer sonorense trabajadora, entregada a su familia y orgullosa por su espíritu de lucha. Estudió la carrera de contaduría, tiene 47 años y ha estado casada por diez. Sus grandes tesoros y en quienes encuentra una motivación diaria son su hija de 24 años, una mujer casada quién terminará en diciembre la carrera de ingeniería, y su nieto de 6 años, a quién desea darle una mejor calidad de vida y un ejemplo de lucha.
Rosa tiene una tienda de abarrotes que inició porque vio una oportunidad con su trabajo de contadurías independientes y la aprovechó. Con esta tienda ha ayudado a sustentar así familia, así como hacerla crecer y desarrollar. El dinero del crédito le está ayudando a invertir en una vitrina de carnes para poder incrementar sus ventas y enfrentar el reto de crecer y convertir su tienda en un mini súper. En un futuro, a Rosa le gustaría poder construir otra tienda de abarrotes en una zona distinta y crear una cadena de tiendas de abarrotes propias.
texts.en:
Rosa Isela is a hard-working woman from Sonora, dedicated to her family and proud of her fighting spirit. She studied accounting. She is 47 years old and has been married for 10 years. Her greatest treasures and her daily motivation are her 24 year old daughter, a married woman who is finishing her engineering degree in December, and her 6 year old grandson, who she wants to give a better quality of life and an example of hard work. 

Rosa has a small grocery store that she started because she saw an opportunity in her independent accounting job and she took advantage of it. With this store she has helped support, grow and develop her family. The loan money will help her invest in a meat display case to increase her sales and face the challenge of growing and turning her small store into a small super market. In the future, Rosa would like to be able to build another small grocery store in another area and create her own chain.

loans.use: to buy a display case to expand her store.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is 20-year-old young man from Jabalia city. Bilal was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Bilal took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house.

The loan will allow Bilal to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Bilal appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Raid

texts.en:
Raid is a 45-year-old married man from Rafah city. Raid was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Raid took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house.

The loan will allow Raid to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Raid appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Sameer

texts.en:
Sameer is 40-year-old married man from Rafah city. Sameer was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Sameer took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house.

The loan will allow Sameer to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Sameer appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Shihadeh

texts.en:
Shihadeh is a 56-year-old married man from Rafah city. He was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Shihadeh took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house.

The loan will allow Shihadeh to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Shihadeh appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
In the past, Trinidad can’t think of means on where to get supplementary fund to run her food business. But when Center for Community Transformation (CCT) approved her previous loan application, it became a way to increase her daily sales as she was able to buy daily ingredients for her food business. 

Most of the amount earned on the business were being used for their day-to-day expenses. Revolving fund is what she wants to retain so that on a daily basis she’ll have spare budget to buy ingredients needed for her food business. Currently, she’s also managing a variety store business that she wants to be progressive as well. With this, she applied for a loan amount of Php 12,000.

Trinidad is an entrepreneur and a mother as well. But one thing that’s also interesting about her is that she wants to continue her studies. She aims to have an established savings account for her to support all their financial aspects. That’s why she exerts extra effort to be successful on those businesses.

Trinidad is consistent in attending weekly fellowship group for CCT partners that consists of 15 to 30 members where she gain spiritual strength for member’s life changing testimony, share her own experience of God’s love, pay Micro Finance loans and  hear God’s word that  was conveyed to them every week.

loans.use: to be used as a revolving fund for her food business and some for buying grocery items for her variety store.

loans.name: Las Amorosas Group

texts.es:
Lo que activa la economía de una comunidad veracruzana es el cultivo de la caña de azúcar, frijol, maíz, sorgo y piña. Allí está ubicado uno de los ingenios azucareros con mayor producción de todo el país. Pertenecientes de dicha comunidad, se encuentra el grupo Las amorosas integrado por 15 mujeres trabajadoras y, huelga decirlo, con un carácter amoroso para sus seres queridos. Ellas son: Rosa y Adulfa quienes vende cosméticos, ropa y calzado; María E., zapatos, recipientes y cosméticos; María H., ropa, zapatos y perfumes; Lucy, zapatos; Santa, comida y ropa; Amairany, zapatos y ropa; Beatriz, platos y zapatos; María R., electrodomésticos y ropa; María A., comida típica y artesanías; Cira, tacos; Guadalupe, cosméticos y ropa; Ashley, bisutería; Magaly, bolsas y artículos de plata y Leticia quien brinda servicio de molino.
   María Elena además de haber criado a sus tres hijos apoya, junto con su marido Manuel, con los gastos necesarios para criar a su pequeño nieto. Hace más de diez años decidió iniciar con una actividad; se ha dedicado a vender  cosméticos y con las ganancias obtenidas y el apoyo de su familia pudo integrar la venta de calzado por catálogo. Progresivamente sus actividades se han enriquecido, las claves de su éxito las atribuye a su buen carácter, excelente trato al cliente y precios accesibles que dejan sin herramientas a cualquier competencia. “Gracias a Dios vendo bastante y he podido ayudar a mi esposo con los gastos” expresa contenta.
   Por otro lado, los préstamos que le han sido otorgados le han sido de utilidad para invertir en la compra de más productos y catálogos, con esto continua obteniendo ganancias favorables. Siempre cumple con sus objetivos y en ocasiones ayuda a cualquiera de sus compañeras para que no afecten sus negocios. En esta ocasión el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de calzado para de distintos tamaños y modelos además de  cosméticos variados. Ella terminó refiriendo: “gracias a quienes han hecho posible cada uno de los prestamos pues con ellos nos brindan nuevas oportunidades de crecimiento”.
*La fotografía fue tomada en el patio trasero de Elena quien viste blusa color vino y está junto a Lucy quien viste blusa color amarilla.
texts.en:
One of the top producing sugar mills in the entire country is located there. The "Las Amorosas" group belongs to the community. It's made of 15 women workers and, needless to say, has a loving character for their loved ones. They are: Rosa and Adulfa who sells cosmetics, clothing and footwear; Mary E., shoes, and cosmetics containers; Maria H., clothes, shoes and perfumes; Lucy, shoes; Santa, food and clothing; Amairany, shoes and clothing; Beatriz, plates and shoes; Maria R., appliances and clothing; Mary A., typical food and crafts; Cira, tacos; Guadalupe, cosmetics and clothing; Ashley, jewelry; Magaly, bags and silverware and Leticia who provides miling services.

In addition to having raised her three children, Maria Elena supports, along with her husband Manuel, the expenses needed to raise her little grandson. More than ten years ago she decided to start a business and has been dedicated to selling cosmetics. With the income earned and the support of her family, she could begin selling shoes by catalog. Gradually her activities have been enriching. She attributes the keys to her success attributes to her good character, excellent customer service and affordable prices that left without any competition. "Thank God I could sell a lot and help my husband with the expenses," she said contently.

On the other hand, the loans she has received have been useful to invest in buying more products and catalogs. With this, she continues earning good income. She always meet her goals and sometimes helps her companions so as to not affect their business. This time, the loan will be invested in the purchase of shoes of different sizes and models in addition to many cosmetics. She concluded, "Thanks to those who have made each of the loans because they provide us with new growth opportunities."

* The photograph was taken in Elena's backyard. She is wearing a burgundy blouse and is next to Lucy, who wears a yellow-colored blouse.

loans.use: to buy shoes for women, men and children and cosmetics (lipstick, eye shadow, mascara, eyeliner, lotions).

loans.name: Khalid

texts.en:
Khalid is a 22-year-old married man from Jabalia city. He was living with his family in a small humble house, but during the latest war in Gaza, his house destroyed completely, then he had to rent a small apartment in the same area.

Recently Khalid took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) in order to rebuild his old house.

The loan will allow Khalid to finalize the needed construction in a short time and return his family to their normal life.

Khalid appears in the photo.

loans.use: to rebuild his old house.

loans.name: Tariq

texts.en:
Tariq is a 41-year-old married man from Dier El Balah city, located in the Gaza Strip. He works as an employee in the public sector where he gets a low income. This income barely covers all the family needs. However, he wants to improve his family standard of living help them live more comfortably.
 
Tariq took a USD loan from FATEN in order to buy a solar system for heating water for the family house. By taking this loan, Tariq will be able heat water more efficiently, enable the family to take warm showers, while also decreasing the electricity expenses.
 
Tariq appears in the photo

loans.use: in order to buy a solar system for heating water for the family house.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
Although William is new to the ice cream business, he has studied the product and its trends for the past ten years. After a successful career in banking, he retired in Florida and decided to start his own ice cream business.

Recently he created his own ice cream recipe and is currently selling it online. William is seeking a loan to purchase inventory for an upcoming jazz festival.

His goal is to take advantage of marketing opportunities and continue to grow his business' presence online.

loans.use: to purchase inventory.

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Modesta is 70 years old, widowed, and has two children. She works very hard to provide for them. Modesta operates a general store in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 26 years.

Modesta requested a loan from NWTF for 29,000 PHP, which she will use to buy additional items such as detergent soap, candies, shampoo, noodles, biscuits, etc. to sell. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items such as detergent soap, candies, shampoo, noodles, biscuits, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa is 33 years old and has one child. Vanessa is married and has one child who is in school.

Vanessa is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Vanessa requested a PHP 14000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Vanessa has been in pig fattening for 5 years now, and has borrowed 6 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Vanessa would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
Sani is a Babban Gona farmer.  Sani is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty, renewing his dreams of gaining wealth someday. Traditionally, Sani would have had to sell his maize at Harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan Sani can store his maize at harvest and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. Benefiting from Babban Gona’s marketing support, Sani has the opportunity to generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. 

Sani is thankful that he no longer has to worry about having no money to pay for his children's school fees and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Ephraim

texts.en:
Ephraim is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, Ephraim has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tonnes of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Ephraim would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With the help of this loan, Ephraim can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Ephraim will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha.

Ephraim is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a university education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Desideria

texts.en:
Desideria is a happy cook. She is 49 years old, married, and has two dependents, aged 17 and 19. She is from the town of Garcia Hernandez, Bohol.

She has two small businesses: selling fried tempura and dried fish. These may be small, but there is a high demand. Tempura is a street food, a Japanese dish of battered fish, shellfish, or vegetables fried to be dipped in sauce. A lot of students buy this for a snack, while dried fish is a staple food in a Filipino household.

She is asking for a loan to buy dried fish and more tempura to sell. Desideria shared that she hopes to have a bigger business in the future through CEVI's loan for her, because she plans to make expansions.

loans.use: to buy dried fish and tempura.

loans.name: Dulcero Group

texts.es:
Existe una comunidad oaxaqueña rodeada por cerros y sembradíos de caña de azúcar, maíz, frijol, papaya y limón. Allí, la calidez de la comunidad es sobresaliente, la mayoría de los habitantes se dedican a trabajar en el campo; muchos de ellos son productores, otros más sólo jornaleros. Sin embargo, lo mejor de la comunidad son sus dulces típicos que se preparan con amor en varios hogares.
   Dulcero es el nombre de un grupo integrado por 12 mujeres trabajadoras quienes siempre han dado todo de sí para brindar lo mejor a su familia; el nombre hace referencia, como ya se mencionó, a la tradición dulcera de la región.  Los miembros son: Paula quien vende comida y tamales; Cecilia, mercería y comida; María, pizza y calzado; Norma, caña de azúcar; Martina, refrescos; Diana, dulces típicos; Brenda, calzado por catálogo; Ma. Antonia, calzado y tamales; Rosa, lencería; Guadalupe, ropa; Ángela, abarrotes y Juana quien cría aves de corral.
   Diana y su esposo José Luis se  convirtieron en padres hace 10 meses y mientras él se dedica a trabajar en el campo, ella prepara y vende dulces tradicionales de la región. Desde pequeña observaba como su madre y su abuela seguían las recetas para elaborar ricos dulces de coco, de leche, ates  y alfajores de maíz y arroz, sólo por mencionar algunos. “Me gusta hacer dulces, es una actividad que durante muchas generaciones ha sido fuente de ingresos en mi familia” comentó alegremente; actualmente tiene tres años ofreciendo el resultado de su receta familiar. Tiene mucha confianza en su producto ya que a pesar de la competencia que existe en la comunidad, logra vender un promedio de 170 a 220 dulces por semana. 
    Las ganancias obtenidas le permiten apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y reinvertir en su negocio. El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de queso panela, maíz, arroz, semilla de pipián, coco, ajonjolí, piña, canela y bolsas para empaquetar toda su producción ya que afortunadamente ésta ha aumentado. Su objetivo principal es crear una marca propia de dulces para convertirse así en un micro empresario.
*La fotografía fue tomada en casa de Brenda, Diana se ubica detrás de doña Ma. Antonia quien viste blusa verde.
texts.en:
There is a Oaxacan community surrounded by hills and fields of sugar cane, corn, beans, papaya and lemon. There, the warmth of the community is outstanding. Most of the inhabitants are dedicated to working in the field; many of them are farmers, others only laborers. However, the best part of the community are the typical sweets prepared with love in various homes.

Dulcero is the name of a 12-working women who have always given their all to give the best to their families. The group name refers, as already mentioned, the confectionery tradition of the region. The members are: Paula, who sells food and tamales; Cecilia, hats and food; Mary, pizza and footwear; Norma, sugar cane; Martina, soft drinks; Diana, traditional sweets; Brenda, footwear by catalog; Ma. Antonia, footwear and tamales.; Rosa, lingerie; Guadalupe, clothing; Angela, groceries and Juana, who raises poultry.

Diana and her husband, Jose Luis, became parents 10 months ago. While he works in the field, she prepares and sells traditional sweets of the region. Since childhood, she watched her mother and grandmother prepare delicious recipes for sweet coconut milk, ates (a fruit sweet) and alfajores (a small cookie) made of corn and rice, to name a few. "I like making candy. It'ss an activity that has been a source of income for many generations in my family," she said cheerfully.

Currently, she's been providing the family recipe for three years. She has a lot of confidence in her product and, despite the competition that exists in the community, manages to sell an average of 170 to 220 candies per week.

The proceeds enable her to support her husband with the household expenses and reinvest in her business. The loan will be invested in the purchase of brown sugar, cheese, corn, rice, squash seed, coconut, sesame, pineapple, cinnamon and bags to package all her production, which has fortunately increased. Her main objective is to create a brand of candy in order to become a micro entrepreneur.

* The photograph was taken at Brenda's house. Diana sits behind Ma. Antonia, who wears green blouse.

loans.use: to buy brown sugar, corn, rice, squash seed, coconut, sesame, pineapple, cinnamon and bags.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita is 62 years old and married with one child. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines.

Julita is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Julita has been raising pigs for 20 years and also earns additional income from a general store and charcoal and firewood vending.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela is 72 years old and a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Adela has a general store business in the Philippines. Adela requested a PHP 20000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell in her general store.

Adela has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, Adela would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol is 39 years old and has six children. She is married and has five children who are currently in school. Mirasol is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines.

Mirasol requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

She has been in pig fattening for 6 years now, and has borrowed 12 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Mirasol would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Mindalina

texts.en:
Mindalina is 49 years old and has nine children. Mindalina is married and has four children who are currently in school.

Mindalina is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Mindalina requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to purchase feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

Mindalina has been raising livestock for 15 years now, and has borrowed 26 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Mindalina would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a maize farmer from Gayya village. As a Babban Gona member, Daniel is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Daniel would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing.

Daniel will use this loan to store the maize he harvests, enabling him to delay it’s sale until a later period in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price. Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Daniel no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/ha, Daniel hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a university education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is a maize farmer from Gayya village. As a Babban Gona member, Samson is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Samson would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Samson no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/ha, Samson hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a university education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: St. Paul Mutorere School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Amando. He is the Head teacher of St. Paul’s Mutorere School, a mixed school in the Rural area of Kisoro with 600 students. St. Paul’s Mutorere School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day.

St. Paul’s Mutorere School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Amando ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his student’s concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: to purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Safet

texts.en:
Safet is a single, 38-year-old male, living in the southern part of Kosovo. He earns a living through his chicken business, purchasing chickens at wholesale and selling them in the market for a higher price. He loves what he does and is very satisfied with his income and business.

At this time Safet is requesting a loan to be able to purchase more chickens to sell at the market.

His goal is to be able to have a small chicken farm and is very optimistic and ambitious to make it happen in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens to sell at the market

loans.name: Xhavahire

texts.en:
Xhevahire and her husband have a business working with tin. They have a workshop in their home, allowing her to be able to work and to take care of the home and children.

Xhevahire's husband started this business based on family tradition and they have a lot of clients with various demands and requests. Usually he builds fences for people's yards and the business is their main source of income.

Xhevahire is requesting a loan of 1,000 euros to purchase material for work; she promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase material for working with tin.

loans.name: Pecesitos Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Pecesitos está conformado por tres mujeres laboriosas, coordinado por Urania de 55 años de edad, casada quien se dedica a la venta de ropa y frijoles cocidos desde hace doce años, solicitan por quinto ciclo el financiamiento de ADIM, para la compra de camisas, pantalones, chores y frijoles, una de sus metas es tener su propia boutique, por otro lado con créditos anteriores logro reinvertir en la compra de mercadería. Las otras socias del grupo son Sandra de 33 años, dedicada a la venta de ropa hace ocho años y Karla de 33 años, también vende ropa y prendas de acero.
texts.en:
The loan group Pecesitos is made up of three hardworking women, led by Urania. She's 55, married and has earned a living selling clothing and cooked beans for 12 years.

She's seeking a fifth cycle of loan money from ADIM to buy shirts, pants, shorts and beans. One of her goals is to have her own boutique. With her earlier loan, she was able to reinvest in buying merchandise.

The other members of the group are Sandra, 33, who has sold clothing for eight years, and Karla, 33, who also sells clothing and steel pieces.

loans.use: to buy shirts, pants, shorts and beans.

loans.name: Jose Roberto William

texts.es: José cuenta con 41 años de edad logro hace 15 años comprar su vivienda en la que vive junto a su esposa y sus dos hijos de 22 y 16 años de edad. José se dedica a prestar sus servicios de albañil en una empresa constructora, con lo que logra sacar adelante a su familia, además los fines de semana realiza pequeños trabajos que solicitan sus vecinos. La conexión eléctrica de la vivienda de José se encuentra deteriorada, por lo que el teme que en cualquier momento suceda un accidente que lastime a su familia, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: cables eléctricos, caja térmica, toma corriente, polo tierra, entre otros materiales para cambiar la instalación eléctrica en su vivienda.
texts.en:
José is 41 years old. Fifteen years ago, he bought his house, where he lives with his wife and two children who are 16 and 22 years old. José earns a living as a bricklayer in a construction business, where he's able to get his family ahead. On the weekends, he also does small jobs for his neighbors.

The electrical connection in José's home has deteriorated and he fears any minute it could cause an accident and hurt his family. As a result, he's seeking a loan from FUSAI to invest in electrical cables, a cooling box, outlet, and a grounding pole, among other materials to change the electrical installation in his house.

loans.use: to invest in electrical cables, a cooling box, outlet,  and a grounding pole, among other materials to rewire.

loans.name: Bawa

texts.en:
Bawa is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Bawa has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Bawa would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs.

With the help of this loan, Bawa can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Bawa will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000/ha.

Bawa is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the lives of his children and family, and looks forward to using his additional earnings to provide employment to members of his community through his farm

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Kasimu

texts.en:
Jafaru is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Jafaru has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Jafaru is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Hannatu

texts.en:
Hannatu is a maize farmer from Madaki village. As a Babban Gona member, she is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give her the chance to achieve high yields of up to eight metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Hannatu would have had to sell her maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Hannatu will use this loan to store the maize she harvests, enabling her to delay its sale until a later period in the season when she can obtain the best price for her maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Hannatu no longer feels the pressure to sell her maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000/Ha, she hopes to realize better yields and plans on using her additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is a small entrepreneur living and working in the Kyiv region. She sells drapes, curtains, pelmets, sheets, towels, etc. She works in a local mall, renting her vending location from the shopping center administration. She has been working in this business for 19 years. Valentina is 54. She is married with a grown son.

Valentina is seeking 40,000 Grivnyas to buy a new assortment of curtains and drapes to restock her merchandise with quality and variety of fast-moving inventory items to offer to her customers.

Valentina is an experienced businesswoman, running this enterprise for many years. She knows what sells and what does not, which is why this investment of funds will definitely be efficient and reasonable.

loans.use: to purchase drapes and net curtains to sell

loans.name: Jose Martin

texts.es:
El  Señor José de 33  años de edad  vive con su esposa en su casa de habitación ubicada en una aldea de Honduras, se dedica al negocio que es la compra y venta de sal desde hace 16 años  sus clientes son las personas del norte del país donde vende su producto, tiene muchos clientes que le encargan sal.
Esta solicitando el crédito para la compra de sal Industrial. Esta muy agradecido por el apoyo que le puede brindar Prisma.
Su sueño es  terminar de pagar su camión.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Septiembre 2015
texts.en:
Jose is 33 years old and lives with his wife in a village in Guayabo. He's been buying and selling salt for 16 years. His clients are from the northern part of the country and he already has many client for his salt.
He's requesting a loan to buy industrial salt. He's very grateful for the support of Prisma. His dream is to finish paying for his truck. San Lorenzo, Honduras - Septiembre 2015

loans.use: to buy industrial salt.

loans.name: Ivanna

texts.en:
Ivanna is 19. She is single and lives with her parents at the moment. Ivanna works for a local company in the position of an administrator. She has been employed there for two years.

Ivanna wants to use 20,000 Grivnyas to do some repair work on the house; she is planning to change two windows and to stucco two front walls of the house.

As a typical girl, Ivanna is hoping and planning to get married some day. She believes that learning to take care of different aspects of routine lifestyle will help her in her future family life as well.

loans.use: to do some repair work on the house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy flour, lard, sugar, margarine and cooking oil

loans.name: Bitrus

texts.en:
Bitrus is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Bitrus is thankful that the days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Bitrus would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bitrus will store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a later date in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize, at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/hectare, Bitrus now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and his family members, and would like to use this additional income to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: México Group

texts.es:
Los integrantes del grupo México están muy orgullosos de sus raíces y de su comunidad la cual es llamada “La novia del sol” debido a sus altas temperaturas. Todas son personas trabajadoras, responsables, honestas y comprometidas con su familia; los lazos de amistad que los unen son muy fuertes. Los integrantes son: María quien vende bisutería; Blandina, ropa y perfumes; Julio y Claudia, comida; Emma, cosméticos; Dulce, ropa y bisutería; Ana, ropa y zapatos; Teodora, perfumes; Ismael, plata y juguetes; Pablo, accesorios computacionales y Víctor quien brinda servicios de publicidad.
   Don Víctor es uno de los integrantes más entusiastas del grupo, tiene como único objetivo cuidar de su familia integrada por su esposa Yolanda y sus tres hijos quienes continúan estudiando. Para cumplir sus metas se ha dedicado desde los dieciocho años al negocio familiar, es decir, que realiza publicidad por distintos medios para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.  Las ganancias obtenidas las emplea en el mantenimiento de la unidad móvil que, entre otras cosas, utiliza con un megáfono con el cual promociona los negocios de su clientela. “Soy feliz al formar parte del negocio familiar y por brindarle con ello lo mejor a mi familia; espero formar un patrimonio para ellos y continuar con la actividad de mis generaciones” comentó contento.
   Como en todo negocio, existen temporadas bajas y altas pero siempre constantes por lo que no tiene ninguna preocupación. De igual modo siente trabajar en una estación de radio local donde puede trasmitir su alegría a diversos hogares, además de ser la fuente informativa en conjunto con el periódico local. La radio igualmente le sirve para publicitar a las personas que lo soliciten. 
   En esta ocasión solicitó un crédito con el fin de invertir en la compra de llantas para su vehículo y una bocina nueva. Finalmente menciona, “gracias por este apoyo, por creer en nosotros pues cada préstamo significa una oportunidad de crecimiento”.
*La fotografía fue tomada en “la novia del sol”, Víctor viste playera blanca y pantalón de mezclilla color gris.
texts.en:
The members of the Mexico group are very proud of their roots and community, which is called "The Bride of the Sun" because of its high temperature. All are working, responsible, honest people committed to their family. The bonds of friendship that unite them are very strong.

The members are: Mary, who sells jewelry; Blandina, clothing and perfumes; Julio and Claudia, food; Emma, cosmetics; Dulce, clothing and jewelry; Ana, clothing and shoes; Teodora, perfumes; Ismael, silver and toys; Pablo, computer accessories and Victor who provides advertising services.

Victor is one of the most enthusiastic members of the group, who aims only to take care of his family, made up of his wife Yolanda and her three children who are in school. To meet his goals, he has been dedicated to the family business for eighteen years, that is, advertising in various mediums to meet the needs of his customers. He uses the earnings to maintain the mobile unit that, among other things, he uses with a megaphone to promote his customers' businesses. "I am happy to join the family business and thereby provide the best for my family. I hope to be an asset to them and continue with the activity of my generation," he said happily.

  As in any business, there are high and low seasons, but business is always constant so he has no worries. He similarly likes working in a local radio station where he can transmit his joy to many homes, as well as being the source of information in conjunction with the local newspaper. The radio also serves to advertise to people who request it.

This time he applied for a loan in order to invest in the purchase of tires for his vehicle and a new speaker. He concluded, "Thanks for this support, for believing in us as each loan means an opportunity for growth."

* The photograph was taken in "The Bride of the Sun." Victor wears a white shirt and gray jeans.

loans.use: to buy wheels for the car and hitch a speaker.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Ali has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Ali would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Ali is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family, and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a university education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

texts.en:

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana has already benefited from Kiva’s assistance before. Financial help from Kiva helped Tatyana get a 2,000 Grivnya increase in her income, which was later invested in major repairs of the house where Tatyana’s family lives.

Tatyana is hoping to finish another project related to remodeling of her house; she is hoping to install six new windows and two interior doors, too.

This project would require an additional amount of 38,000 Grivnyas which Tatyana doesn’t have at the moment and that is why she turned to Kiva for help.

loans.use: to install six new windows and two interior doors.

loans.name: Vasil

texts.en:
Vasil is from Mukachevo. He works as a security agent at the local train station. Vasil has been in this position for the last three years. He is 28, single, and lives with his parents. One of Vasil’s biggest hobbies is fishing.

Vasil is seeking 20,000 Grivnyas to change electric wiring, switches and sockets, and to insulate the outside wall with fiberglass.

Vasil is also hoping to plaster and paint the walls and ceiling, as well as to tile the floor in the room where he lives in his parents’ house. Vasil is planning to do all the work himself. He needs additional funding to buy required supplies and materials to finish this project.

loans.use: to change electric wiring, switches and sockets, and to insulate the outside wall with fiberglass.

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en:
Franklin is a 44-year-old married man from Moalboal, Cebu. He has three children aged 8-15. He has been engaged in the hog-raising business for two years now. He earns PHP2000 per month. This is his only source of income.

Franklin is requesting for a loan to buy feed for his pigs and additional piglets to add in his small wooden barn. Through this loan, he can supply what his pigs need to grow faster. In the future, Franklin hopes to expand his business and to earn more profit.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is a native from the town of Tolosa, Leyte. She is married woman and has eight children. Her oldest child is 21, while the youngest is 7. She earns a living by selling fruits such as mango and pineapple. For the past five years as a fruit vendor, she mostly caters to town dwellers in the place where she lives.

She would like to have additional capital in order to have an adequate supply of fruits. These would attract potential customers and slowly improve her livelihood. Therefore, Emily has requested a loan to purchase a variety of fruits. With these, she could cater to the needs of her respective customers. Thus, she could be able to provide her family with a healthy diet and better shelter to live in. She is looking forward to improving her business to become more sustainable in order to finance the schooling of all of her children for a brighter future.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of fruits to sell.

loans.name: Melvy

texts.es: Melvy de 39 años de edad vive en casa propia con su hija, ella se dedica a la venta de medicina popular de manera ambulante por las diferentes y con lo que obtiene de sus ventas es como ha podido salir adelnete con su hija, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda cambiando puertas y ventanas pero con lo que gana no le alcanza para realizarlo por esa razon solicita un credito para la compra de balcones, puertas, ventanas y paga de mano de obra para tener una vivienda mas segura.
texts.en: Melvy is 39 years old and lives in a house she owns with her daughter. She makes a living as a walking saleswoman, selling popular medicine and with what she obtains from her sales she has been able to get ahead with her daughter. She wants to improve her home, replacing the doors and windows, but what she earns is not enough to do this. For this reason she is asking for a loan to buy balconies, doors and windows, and to pay for labor to have a safer home.

loans.use: to buy balconies, doors, and windows, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores lives in a town of Concepcion in Iloilo, Philippines. She is married and has two children ages 13 and 9 years old. Her husband is a fisherman while Dolores runs her small grocery store to earn a living. She has been doing this business for more than 12 years. She works hard with her husband to provide good education to their children. Thus, she is asking a bigger amount of loans to buy commodities such as chocolate bars, chips, candies, bread, biscuits, toiletries, spices, sugar, powdered milk and chocolate drink, noodles, canned goods and drinks. In the future, Dolores dreams to improve their livelihood to have enough money to send her children to school. She wants them to finish in their studies and get a degree.

loans.use: to buy chocolate bars, chips, candies, bread, biscuits, toiletries, spices, sugar, powdered milk and chocolate drink, noodles, canned goods and drinks

loans.name: Merlinia

texts.en: Merlinia and her husband are engaged in fishing business like most people in Iloilo, Philippines. Merlinia and her family lives in the Town of Concepcion Iloilo. They raised their 10 children for more than 25 years by doing this business. Among these 10 children, she only has four-school-aged children who still need their support. Merlinia is asking a loan to buy materials for boat repair such as plywood, nails and boat repair glue. They need this to help them improve their catch. Merlinia wishes to increase their livelihood to have enough money to send all her school children to school. She wants them to finish their degree to have better lives in the future.

loans.use: to buy materials for boat repair such as plywood, nails and boat repair glue

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
From Moalboal, Cebu Lucia, a 68-year-old grandmother with six-year-old granddaughter, has been raising pigs for ten years, earning 8,000 PHP a month. She has requested a loan to buy feed and piglets in order to sustain her business.
In the future, Lucia would like to expand to her enterprise so as to better provide healthy meals for herself and her husband who is a farmer.

loans.use: to buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en: Nena lives in Trinidad, Bohol. She has run a farming business since 2000. She also operate a Sari-sari store business in the area. She and her support  two children ages 16 and 19. With the money that she applied for a loan, she plans to use it for the purchase of farming maintenance like fertilizer and merchandise such as canned sardines, corned beef, sausages, seasoning, condiments and toiletries. The additional income will go to her children’s education and the family's daily consumption.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her crops and also supplies for her general store

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a married woman from Concepcion, Iloilo. She is 44 years old and a mother of two children; ages 21 and 8 years old. She earns a living by running a sari-sari store (general store) business. Aside from this, she also helps her husband in fishing. Although she and her husband work together, still the profit that they earn is not enough. That is why; Marilyn comes up into a decision of borrowing money to operate their business continuously.

She is asking a bigger amount of loans for additional capital to buy grocery items such as noodles, canned goods, eggs, cooking oil, coffee, powdered milk, powdered chocolate drink, sugar, toiletries, candies, chips, biscuits and drinks. Marilyn wants to have enough capital to run her business for sustainability. Precisely, she is so thankful for the money we entrusted to her to help her reach her goal.

loans.use: to buy noodles, canned goods, eggs, cooking oil, coffee, powdered milk, powdered chocolate drink, sugar, toiletries, candies, chips, biscuits and drinks

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en: Nestor is a resident of Ajuy, Iloilo where fishing is one of their main sources of income in most people in the community. He is a married man and has two children and he is raising them through this fishing business. He has been doing this since then as he started his married life and hoping to augment this livelihood because it is the only business that he can get an income to provide his family. Thus, he is asking for a loan to help him buy new fishing net to enhance his catch. Nestor dreams in the future to improve his livelihood for his children’s education. He wants them to give good life and better means of living.

loans.use: to buy fishing net

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en: Shirly lives a simple life in a town of Concepcion, Iloilo. She is married and has four-school-aged children. Her husband is a fisherman while Shirly helps her husband by selling their catch. Aside from this, she also buys additional fish and sea foods from other fishermen to increase her sales. She and her husband have been operating this business for 10 years. She is asking a bigger amount of loans to buy more fish to sell. She will also use the loan for boat maintenance. In the future, Shirly wishes to improve their livelihood and have better means of living.

loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Segundo Wilder

texts.es:
Segundo con 36 años de edad,de estado civil soltero,vive junto a sus padres, en el distrito de Cayaltí,provincia de Chiclayo,departamento de Lambayeque,país Perú.Los habitantes de esta localidad se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura y ganadería.

Segundo se dedica a prestar servicio como jornalero agrícola por zona de residencia,desde hace más de 03 años de experiencia en el rubro.Solicita préstamo para la compra de animales como pavos,pollos,cuyes,etc y comida para estos. De esta manera le facilitará seguir trabajando y obtener mayores ingresos.

Segundo no cuenta con experiencia crediticia, es socio nuevo para Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
Segundo, 36 years old, is single, and lives with his parents in the district of Cayaltí, in Chiclayo province, Lambayeque department, in the country of Peru. The people in this locality work primarily in agriculture and raising animals.

Segundo works as a farm laborer in the zone where he lives, with over 3 years of experience in this field. He asks for a loan for the purchase of animals like ducks, chickens, and guinea pigs. In this way, it will make it easier for him to continue working and to get more income.

Segundo does not have any credit experience, he is a new borrower for Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy animals like ducks, chickens, and guinea pigs

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en:
Alhaji is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Alhaji is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer. 

Traditionally, Alhaji would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alhaji will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a later date in the season when he can obtain up to 37% more than the harvest price. 

With the opportunity to earn up to $2000/ha, Alhaji has the opportunity to realize his dream to grow his agriculture business for him and his family. He would like to use the additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Kasmeri

texts.en:
Good day lenders! Meet one of KPP UMKM’s clients, Kasmeri, who is a 52-year-old married woman with two sons and one daughter.

Kasmeri is a housewife and her husband has been an employee for 20 years.

She has asked for a loan of IDR 7,200,000 from KPP-UMKM Syariah. This loan will be used to build a toilet and water source at their home to improve sanitation. Her family income is insufficient to build a toilet and water source, but Kasmeri will be able to repay the loan received.

She and her family want to live a healthy life with healthy sanitation and clean water. She is very grateful for the opportunity and wants to thank to all lenders.

loans.use: to build a toilet and water source at their home.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en: Annah has always desired to own a biogas system, but she has never found a reliable installer and the overall cost of most installers is also prohibitive. She learned about Takamoto biogas through a neighbour and was interested in their biogas loan. She contacted them and they were willing to install the biogas for her. With this system she will be able to own a biogas system and will enjoy convenient fuel.

loans.use: to buy a system for clean, renewable fuel for cooking.

loans.name: Paola Carina

texts.en:
Paola is 25 year old woman, she is currently married to a loving husband and not so long ago she became a mother to a young baby. Paola's house is mainly supported by her husband, nevertheless she like to contribute to the total house income, to do so she works hard on her food stand.
She works hard on her food stand, mostly sells tacos and quesadillas, she like her work because she knows that with it she will be able to provide a better life for her baby.
Paola's baby is growing fast and soon is going to need a room of his own, and to built it Paola is seeking a 9,500.00 MXN loan, Paola counts with her husband's full support for this project and is really keen on it because she sees it as a great opportunity to give something special for her young child.

loans.use: to build her baby's room

loans.name: Santa Rosa Group

texts.es: La Alcancía Comunal “SANTA ROSA” está conformada por 05 socias entusiastas. Este es el caso de Marisol de 43 años de edad, separada con 02 hijos. Marisol es una madre empeñosa que con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación trata de sacar adelante a su familia. Ella tiene una bodega en su casa donde vende todo tipo de abarrotes y bebidas gaseosas. El deseo de Marisol es ampliar su negoció. Solicito el crédito para la compra de azúcar arroz fideos y gaseosas. El grupo “santa rosa” agradece a Kiva por la ayuda brindada. Marisol es la tercera del lado derecho viste polo color fucsia.
texts.en: The Santa Rosa lending group is made up of 5 enthusiastic members. One of them is Marisol, who is 43 years old and is separated with 2 children. Marisol is a diligent mother who is striving with great effort and dedication to raise her family. She has a store in her house where she sells all kinds of groceries and carbonated soft drinks. Her wish is to enlarge her store. She is requesting a loan to buy sugar, rice, noodles, and carbonated drinks. The Santa Rosa group is grateful to Kiva for the help provided. Marisol is the third person on the right in the photo, wearing a pink polo shirt.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, noodles and soft drinks.

loans.name: Ovidia

texts.es: Con 61 años de edad Ovidia continua demostrando sus deseos de superación, ella vive con su hija de 39 años de edad y sus dos nietos de 18 y 17 años de edad. Ovidia se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras actividad que realiza desde hace 45 años, por lo que cuenta con una gran clientela que siempre espera por sus productos. Ovidia desea construir un muro de retención, ya que por lo quebrado de su terreno teme que las lluvias sigan lavándolo y su vivienda, corra peligro, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: cemento, piedra, grava, arena y hierro para construir un muro de retención en su propiedad y de esta manera proteger a su familia.
texts.en:
At 61 years old Ovidia continues to demonstrate her desire to excel. She lives with her 39 year old daughter and her two grandchildren aged 18 and 17 years old. Ovidia works selling fruits and vegetables, a business she has done for 45 years. So she has a large clientele who always wait for her products.

Ovidia wants to construct a retaining wall as the land is uneven and the rains wash over the land and her house and is dangerous. So she is requesting a loan from FUSAI to invest in cement, stone, gravel, sand and re-bar to construct a containing wall on her property and in this way protect her family.

loans.use: to invest in cement, stone, gravel, sand and re-bar to construct a containing wall on her property.

loans.name: Don De Dios Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Don de Dios está conformado por tres mujeres emprendedoras, coordinado por Adela de 54 años de edad, casada y madre de siete hijos quienes son independientes y le ayudan a trabajar para el crecimiento del negocio, ella se dedica a la venta de nacatamales y sopa desde hace tres años, una de sus metas es aumentar la oferta de comida por esta razón solicita el crédito para comprar; maíz leña, carne de cerdo, repollo y tomate. Con el crédito anterior logro emprender un nuevo negocio que fue un taller de carpintería. La segunda socia es Cinthya de 24 años de edad, quien se dedica a la venta de ropa y acero y la tercer socia es Anna de 30 años, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa y calzado.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Don de Dios is comprised of three entrepreneurial women, and headed by Adela. She is 54 years old, married, and the mother of seven children who are independent and help her work for the growth of her business. For three years she has worked selling tamales and soup. One of her goals is to expand the dishes she offers. For this reason she is seeking a loan to buy corn, firewood, pork, cabbage and tomato.

With the previous loan she was able to start a new business, a carpentry shop. The other members are Cinthya who is 24 years old and sells clothes and steel, and Anna who is 30 years old and sells clothes and footwear.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, pork, cabbage and tomato.

loans.name: Inmer Yohao

texts.es:
Inmer, vive con su esposa de 29 años de edad y su madre la cual tiene 59 años de edad, todos son personas trabajadoras, su negocio es vender pollos indios y elotes en el mercado municipal, actividad que realiza desde aproximadamente 3 años.
Con el crédito podrá comprar pollos indios y elotes para revender en el mercado, le ayudará a tener mercadería disponible para atender a sus clientes y aprovechar los precios en los que le ofrecen la mercadería. 
Su sueño es tener un negocio más grande y reparar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Inmer lives with his 29-year-old wife and his 59-year-old mother. They are all very hardworking people. His business is to sell Indian chickens and corn ears in the municipal market, a trade that he has performed for approximately 3 years.

With the loan he will be able to purchase Indian chicken and corn ears to resell in the market, it will help him to have merchandise available to serve his customers and take advantage of the merchandise prices offered to him.

His dream is to have a bigger business and to repair his home.

loans.use: to purchase Indian chickens and corn ears to resell them in the market.

loans.name: Mathias

texts.en:
Mathias is a maize farmer. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Mathias also does charcoal trade to attain increased income to support his family.

Before joining UGAFODE, Mathias would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs.

With the help of this loan, Mathias can store his maize and sell it at a future date for higher than the market price at harvest. As a UGAFODE Microfinance member, Mathias will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings.

Mathias is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land.

Mathias will use the loan to buy more charcoal for trade.

loans.use: to buy charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Odili Del Rosario

texts.es:
Odili es una mujer de 48 años, dueña de una pulpería que está ubicada en su casa, desde hace veinte años.
El préstamo que Odili solicita lo requiere para incrementar su negocio, ya que, su mayor anhelo es tener una gran pulpería donde se encuentre de todo tipo de productos, entonces con este crédito Odili planea comprar arroz, frijoles, aceite, jugos, galletas entre otros. De esta manera podra ofertar mayor cantidad de productos para ofrecer en su tienda y de esta forma aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Odili is 48 years old and for the past 20 years has owned a corner store located in her house. The loan Odili seeks is needed to expand her business, since her greatest desire is to have a big store that sells all types of products.

With this loan Odili plans to buy rice, beans, oil, juices, and crackers, among other things. In this manner she will be able to offer a great quantity of products in her store, thereby increasing her earnings.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, oil, juices and crackers, among other things.

loans.name: Jazmina De Los Angeles

texts.es:
Jazmina es una mujer de 37 años, que inició su negocio con una fritanga, y que ahora se dedica a la venta de ropa.
Su negocio está ubicado en su casa, y con ayuda de su hija y esposo ha logrado hacerlo crecer, sin embargo, Jazmina quiere seguir agrandando su negocio y de esta forma trasladar su tienda al mercado, ya que ahí las ventas son mejores y le dejarán ganancias más amplias, es por tal razón que Jazmina solicita el préstamo, para invertirlo en su tienda y comprar camisas, pantalones, camisolines, calcetines, camisetas entre otros de esta manera podra suplir la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Jazmina is a 37 year old woman who started her business selling fried food and now works selling clothes. 

She runs her business from her house and has been able to grow it with the help of her daughter and husband. However, Jazmina wants to continue to expand her business and so move her shop to the market, where sales are higher and she will earn more income. Jazmina is therefore requesting this loan to invest it in her shop and buy shirts, trousers, camisoles, socks, t-shirts, etc., in order to meet her customers' needs.

loans.use: to buy shirts, trousers, camisoles, socks, t-shirts, etc.

loans.name: Zuwaira

texts.en:
Zuwaira is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Zuwaira has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tones of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. 

Before joining Babban Gona, Zuwaira would have had to sell her maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With the help of this loan, Zuwaira can store her maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Zuwaira will benefit from marketing support that could see her generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. 

Zuwaira is thankful that she now has the opportunity to improve the life of her children and family and looks forward to using her additional earnings to provide employment to members of her community through her farm.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thus eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Shafiu

texts.en:
Shafiu is a maize farmer from Damari village.As a member of Babban Gona, Shafiu is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support he has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes per hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Shafiu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Shafiu can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Shafiuis grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and in the end hopes to use his increased earnings to ensure that all his children get university education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, Mathew has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tones of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. 

Before joining Babban Gona, Mathew would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With the help of this loan, Mathew can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Mathew will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. 

Mathew is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a university  education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en:
Abubakar is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, Abubakar has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tones of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. 

Before joining Babban Gona, Abubakar would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With the help of this loan, Abubakar can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.
